div1.p: Scannell writes about his yellow fever work in Mexico. He encloses a sketch showing key points where the sanitation inspectors will work throughout the season.

Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
Doctor Pierce was with us a few days ago
and I was very glad to see him after all
these years - I did not recognize him
without his beard also he appears much
thinner than in the years when he was
wont to look us over at Colon. He said
he saw Miss Carter and yourself at
Washington prior to his departure and that
you were both well for which I am very
glad. Am sorry you could not come down
also for I should like to have you pass
once more on my work.

Doctor Pierce looked over the work but
was unable to find any breeders and said
he did not believe we had any mosquitoes
here.

Nothing has been reported thus far in this
area.

I am working from Papantla south to and
including Montemorelos north - have not
done anything as yet with Monterrey except
make a survey there - that was last month
when I found an index of 9 per cent total
house and practically all were culex. The
city has an altitude of I500 feet and their
winter season is right cold. Shall make another
survey within the next few days to determine

I spent a few days also at the border last
month but it was a little too early to
definitely determine what the hazard is
as regards Aedes calopus.

At Tampico our total index is running
about I.5 per cent while the Aedes are
50 per cent of total. In addition to
Tampico I am working Panuco with a total
of about I per cent also I am covering
such key points (west) as Tempoal,
Tantoyuca and Huautla, these last named
places control the mountain trails leading
to the coastal plain.

The only area giving me any concern just
now is that vast uncertain territory between
Monterrey and the border - up to this time
however there has been not even a suggestion
of anything there and I am inclined to think
we have the disease eliminated however I
shall carry on and we should know surely
within the next three months whether or no
the Leptospira lurks in our midst.

Doctor's Connor and Vaughs tell me they have
nothing in southern Mexico which sounds very
encouraging.

I am enclosing a little sketch showing
our key points at present being worked
and where we plan to continue throughout
the season.

Our weather is very warm - it is running
about 90 degrees F. through the middle of
day and the nights are very warm also.
50 per cent of all house breeders at present
are stegs.

Please commend me to Miss Laura and accept
my best wishes for yourself - I trust you
continue well.
